title: Elise Hachfeld

library(htmltools)
library(envalysis)

# Import Nursing Home Data 
# https://data.cms.gov/provider-compliance/cost-report/skilled-nursing-facility-cost-report
nursing_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/elisefeld/elise_data_dump/main/nursing_data.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  select(-nursing_and_allied_health_education_activities)

  problems(dat)

  clean_names() |>
  select(-standard) |>
  mutate(state = str_to_lower(state))

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Import US States Data Using sf and maps Packages
states_sf <- read_sf("https://rstudio.github.io/leaflet/json/us-states.geojson") |>
  select(name, geometry) |>
  mutate(name = str_to_lower(name))

states_polygon <- map_data("state") |>
  select(region, group, order, lat, long)

# Import State Population Data 
# https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/articles/2022/04/25/a-third-of-states-lost-population-in-2021
pop_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/elisefeld/elise_data_dump/main/2020_pop.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  mutate(state = str_to_lower(state))

title: Mini_Project_1
text:
Plot 1 (Numeric variable)









      min       Q1   median       Q3      max     mean       sd     n missing
 21.07186 43.97446 51.82551 62.96279 101.0228 53.93941 16.72434 15527       0


Alt-Text: This choropleth plot displays the 48 contiguous US states colored by the number of nursing home beds available per 10,000 people. The data ranges from about 21 to 101 beds per 10,000 people. The western half of the US has a relatively low number of beds, while the Midwest has more. Iowa has the greatest number of beds. The data were obtained from the Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report and 2020 Decennial Population Data.
SANILAC COUNTY MEDICAL CARE FACILITY of MI had 22,287 beds and was removed from the data for this analysis.

title: Mini_Project_1
text:
Plot 2 (categorical variable)
Note: I created both my categorical variables from numerical variables in the data set because there weren’t any appropriate existing variables.









Alt-Text: This choropleth plot displays the 48 contiguous US states colored by the most common type of ownership for nursing homes in the state. The three types of ownership are Nonprofit, Proprietary and Governmental. All of the states are dominated by Proprietary nursing homes except for four: North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota have more Nonprofit nursing homes than other types and Indiana has more Governmental nursing homes. The data were obtained from the Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report.

title: Mini_Project_1
text:
Plot 2 (categorical)
Note: there are no observations in the $20 million - $25 million category so I did not provide a color for that level.


[1] "Less than $10 million"     "$10 million - $15 million"
[3] "$15 million - $20 million" "Greater than $25 million" 






TWIN FOUNTAINS HOME of GA had a gross revenue of $1,300,406,865 and was removed for this analysis.

title: United States Nursing Home Data
text:
Plot 1 (Numeric variable)

nursing_summary |>
  ggplot(aes(long, lat, group = group)) + 
  geom_polygon(aes(fill = beds_10k), color = "black") + 
  labs(title = "Nursing Home Beds Available Nationwide",
       fill = "Beds Per\n10,000 People",
       caption = "Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report (Data.CMS.gov)\n2020 Decennial Population Data (pewtrusts.org) ") +
  coord_map() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0),
                plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
                legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")) +
  scale_fill_viridis()  







favstats(~beds_10k, data = nursing_summary)

      min       Q1   median       Q3      max     mean       sd     n missing
 21.07186 43.97446 51.82551 62.96279 101.0228 53.93941 16.72434 15527       0


Alt-Text: This choropleth plot displays the 48 contiguous US states colored by the number of nursing home beds available per 10,000 people. The data ranges from about 21 to 101 beds per 10,000 people. The western half of the US has a relatively low number of beds, while the Midwest has more. Iowa has the greatest number of beds. The data were obtained from the Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report and 2020 Decennial Population Data.
SANILAC COUNTY MEDICAL CARE FACILITY of MI had 22,287 beds and was removed from the data for this analysis.

title: United States Nursing Home Data
text:
Plot 2 (categorical variable)
Note: I created both my categorical variables from numerical variables in the data set because there weren’t any appropriate existing variables.

nursing_summary |>
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group)) + 
    geom_polygon(aes(fill = top_control_type), color = "black") + 
    coord_map() + 
    theme_void() +  
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0),
                plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
                legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")) +
  labs(title = "Most Common Type of Nursing Home Ownership",
       fill = "Type of Control",
       caption = "Data: Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report (Data.CMS.gov)") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("#77AB43", "#008FD5", "#FF2700"))








Alt-Text: This choropleth plot displays the 48 contiguous US states colored by the most common type of ownership for nursing homes in the state. The three types of ownership are Nonprofit, Proprietary and Governmental. All of the states are dominated by Proprietary nursing homes except for four: North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota have more Nonprofit nursing homes than other types and Indiana has more Governmental nursing homes. The data were obtained from the Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report.

title: United States Nursing Home Data
text:
Plot 1 (numeric)

nursing_summary <- nursing_summary |>
  mutate(num_labs_1 = str_c(name, ": ", snf_mean_stay_round, " days"))
pal <- colorNumeric("Blues", nursing_summary$snf_mean_stay_round)


leaflet(nursing_summary) |>
  addTiles() |> 
  setView(lng = -96.25,
          lat = 40,
          zoom = 3.5) |>
  addPolygons(weight = 2,
              opacity = 1,
              color = "black",
              fillColor = ~ pal(nursing_summary$snf_mean_stay_round),
              fillOpacity = 0.7,
              label = ~ num_labs_1,
              highlightOptions = highlightOptions(weight = 4,
                                                  color = "#668",
                                                  fillOpacity = 0.8,
                                                  bringToFront = TRUE),
              labelOptions = labelOptions(style = list("font-weight" = "normal",
                                                       padding = "3px 8px"),
                                          textsize = "15px",
                                          direction = "auto")) |>
  addLegend(pal = pal,
            values = ~ nursing_summary$snf_mean_stay_round,
            title = paste("Average SNF<br>Stay Length"),
            position = "bottomright")

title: United States Nursing Home Data
text:
Plot 2 (categorical)
Note: there are no observations in the $20 million - $25 million category so I did not provide a color for that level.

nursing_summary <- nursing_summary |>
mutate(cat_labs_1 = paste0("Total Gross Revenue: ", tot_gross_revenue, "<br>",
                         "Number of Nursing Homes: ", homes_per_state, "<br>",
                         "Average Gross Revenue Per Home: ", tot_revenue_homes_round))
        
labels <- lapply(nursing_summary$cat_labs_1, HTML)

levels(nursing_summary$revenue_cat)

[1] "Less than $10 million"     "$10 million - $15 million"
[3] "$15 million - $20 million" "Greater than $25 million" 

factpal <- colorFactor(c("#8FDA04FF",
                         "#009F3FFF",
                         "#132157FF",
                         "#FFF800FF"),
                       levels(nursing_summary$revenue_cat))


leaflet(nursing_summary) |>
  setView(lng = -96.25,
          lat = 40,
          zoom = 3.5) |>
  addTiles() |> 
  addPolygons(weight = 2,
              opacity = 1,
              color = "black",
              fillColor = ~ factpal(nursing_summary$revenue_cat),
              dashArray = "1",
              fillOpacity = 0.7,
  highlightOptions = highlightOptions(weight = 5,
                                      color = "#666",
                                      fillOpacity = 0.7,
                                      bringToFront = TRUE),
  label = labels,
  labelOptions = labelOptions(style = list("font-weight" = "normal",
                                           padding = "3px 8px"),
                              textsize = "15px",
                              direction = "auto")) |>
  addLegend(pal = factpal,
            values = ~ nursing_summary$revenue_cat, 
            opacity = 0.7,
            title = "Gross Revenue",
            position = "bottomright")





TWIN FOUNTAINS HOME of GA had a gross revenue of $1,300,406,865 and was removed for this analysis.
